ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: SABIDURA: El aprendizaje ocurri a travs del textos y obras artsticas sobre temas como la inmigracin, las mujeres, la afro-latinidad, la alteridad y la posverdad, y el indigenismo.
I gained a lot more content-specific vocabulary in this class, specifically learning how to analyze films and how to talk about social, economic, and political issues in Spanish.

Cultural language in spanish; especially more familiarity with social and cultural understanding of historically marginalized groups and their legacies. Different mediums of representation as well, including film, art, writing, etc.
Improved Spanish skills, learned about many artists, and more about the world
L4 is mostly focused on reading and discussing academic material. It was still engaging, just a bit dry sometimes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: The texts, movies, cortometrajes, and artworks used in the class are really good, as are the major themes of the course. 

Weaknesses: L4 de-emphasizes vocabulary and grammar in place of culture and applying what has been learned already. I have since lost vocabulary and grammar structures from previous courses. Also, I think that the course picks some works that are really generative for thought but we didn't get to discuss them because we had to focus on the technical aspects of production, like film angles or brush strokes. I feel like in both Spanish and English I'm much more likely to talk about racism against Afro-Latinas than a panorama in a movie, so I hope that the class puts less of an emphasis on technical analysis of how the works were made.

I think each assignment was pretty well-crafted and the class assignments (surprisingly) rarely felt like busy work. The content, especially the first unit on cultural and gendered representations of witches, was pretty interesting. For these reasons, I liked this class a lot more than my former Spanish classes which focused much more on linguistic conventions and grammar rather than conversational and interdisciplinary applications of the language. In terms of weaknesses, I don't think I learned that much from the projects. They were definitely creative and kind of fun, but I think some of the projects (especially the TikTok and the artistic intervention) were just fundamentally strange as school assignments and I didn't improve my Spanish or learn much from completing them.
Strengths - personal interventions and artistic projects designed around the course; weaknesses - the curriculum per class often times is not completely finished.
Interesting material, not too many tests on vocab, more on writing and material. These are all strengths

The class was very well organized and we were made aware of expectations before every assignment. The professor was also very forgiving when it came to missed deadlines. However, over all, he was the harshest grader of all of my Spanish professors so far.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, L4 is a good course and very different from L3.

I would only recommend this course if you need to take it to fulfill your language requirement. Ian Russell is probably the best Spanish teacher I've ever had though, so definitely try to get into his section if possible!

Yes, it is a chance to develop your critical thinking in a way that allows you to develop your Spanish skills without overthinking your grammar. Furthermore, because of the continuous forms of assessment your grammar skills naturally improve.
Yes - this amplified my cultural understanding as well as encouraging more comfort with using spanish in normal speech.
Yes, but with another professor unless you have a lot of time to dedicate to the class.
